In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. Following the unveiling of Windows 8, Microsoft faced criticism (particularly from free software supporters) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 have secure boot enabled by default using a key provided by Microsoft. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. An obvious workaround for longer recordings was to release a set of records. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. An adolescent 's environment plays a huge role in their identity development . While most adolescent studies are conducted on white , middle class children , studies show that the experiences are much more varied in different communities . In this study , we focus on Latino adolescents in the San Antonio area . This city is an urban environment in Texas , and has a large population of Lat ina/os . The present study focuses on the importance of environment on adoles cen t identity construction . To extend and consolidate the dynasty 's control in Central Asia , the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia . The Dzungars also attacked several Ming outposts in Mongolia and China . The Qianlong Emperor ' s later campaigns were directed against the Dz oungar Khanate ( located in Central Asia ) , which was founded by Mongol refugees in the 17th century . The Dz uongars had attacked neighboring Russian settlements in the Amur and Ob rivers for the previous decades . China s policy towards Central Asia focused mainly on the protection of the Chinese frontiers and the suppression of hostile nom ads , leading to a total disregard of the area 's strategic potential . The 18 th century Chinese leaders were not willing to risk a major engagement of the imperial army in an unfamil iar environment , or the costly task of subduing the people and establishing local administration in these frontiers . From the 1970s onward , Stuart Hall 's pioneering work , along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis , Dick Hebdige , Tony Jefferson , and Angela McRobbie , gave voice to the interests of ordinary people as never previously seen in the academic study of culture . In their work , social science and cultural studies were brought together . In recent years , their concerns and questions have been applied to many areas of social life and culture , including youth culture , fashion , music , film and television , as well as the state , education and more recently the politics of sport . Stuart Hall , one of the most influential of all contemporary social theorists , has written on all these subjects and many more . The earliest samples of pottery recovered at this site , dated 4680 BC , belong to the pre-pottery Neolithic B ( PPNB ) ceramic horizon , which covers the 8th to 7th millennium BC . It was preceded by the PNIB horizon , spanning from 8 800 to 8 000 BC , and distinguished from it mostly by its pottery and the introduction of horses into western Eurasia . Knowledge , for Popper , was objective , both in the sense that it is objectively true ( or truthlike ) , and also in the sense that knowledge has no meaning for the subject . ( This idea is called `` correlationism `` ) . For Popper , however , knowledge also applies to objects , just as we would think . In the language of Popper , knowledge can be understood as `` knowledge of the truth of the given hypothesis about what reality is like . ” “ True ” here means that we should be able to have some grounds for the conviction that the hypothesis is true . According to Popper , only science can give us good knowledge of the truth . He saw science as a kind of game , in which human rational capac ities can be exert ed . Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom , the political structure of which served in most instances [ citation needed ] as a model for the federal system . The Executive and the Legislative Branch together comprise the bic ameral Parliament of The United Kingdom ; the Crown ( i.e . the sovereign ) plays a formal role at times , but the actual day-to-day business of the Government is managed by an elected Prime Minister and his or her Cabinet , which the Parliament may remove at any time . The judiciary comprises the Supreme Court and other courts of the High Court . Each of these branches of Government contains both those directly elected by the people and those appointed by elected members of Parliament and the Executive . The Prime Minister typically has the confidence of the House of Commons , so that the Executive in The United Kingdom serves as a check on the powers of the other branches of Government . Throughout the 14th century , French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility . They ran into difficulties when attempting to impose new taxes without the consent of the lesser nobility . In response , nobles banded together to protest by forming alliances with one another . The nobles of Ile de France began signing contracts ( traitres ) in 1354 in an effort to strengthen their alliances . The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma . During the early Jurassic , the supercontinent Pangaea broke up into the northern supercontinent Laurasia and the southern supercontinent Gondwana . At the same time , the ocean gap between the two new supercont i nents began to close , resulting in warm , shallow marine conditions that had a strong influence on the life of the period . Some regions developed unique animal and plant assemblages . These assemblages were later to become extinct in places that became land masses . For that reason , these regions , as fossils , became important for palaeonthropological studies . The Triassic period began about ; the Per mo-Triassic Boundary ( PTB ) began with a sudden extinction event in which more than half of the ocean genera , the marine biota of the oceans of the Earth disappeared . In particular , the educational system has increasing numbers of English teachers . Teaching Hebrew as a second language is therefore also becoming a growing profession , thus bringing about a growing interest in theoretical and applied linguistics and second – language acquisition research in general . The goal of this chapter is therefore to discuss in an accessible way some key concepts in second - language acquisition research that educators of Hebrew learners should be aware of . According to historical records , the arrival of the Cel ts in the peninsula was recorded around 1 , 200 BCE . The Celts were divided into two groups , the Ilergetoi and the Goidelts , and were known for their ferocity in war as well as their love of gold ; the gold was transported to the northwest via the river Duero . From the year to they arrived , Galicia was occupied by the Celtic Lus itanians , known for their culture and their craft in sculpture and bronze . Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle . For most , the search for identity begins in the adolescent years . During these years , adolescents are searching within and without for some clue to their “ true selves ” . As young people begin to define themselves and discover their places in their families , friendships , and the wider world , adolescent identity development begins . Identity development occurs through the processes of differentiation and integration . Differentiation refers to the separation from parents and the development of an identity away from the family of origin . Integr ation , on the other hand , refers to an emergent sense of connected ness with one ’ s peers and the larger society . At this stage , the young person is seeking to figure out the true meaning of life . During this stage , parents should encourage the child to explore new ways of living as well as to find out as much as possible about other cultures .

Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths . In most Jewish populations , these studies seem to support a recent model for the origins of Jewish communities , i . e a long time ago a small set of founders ( perhaps just a handful of families ) were formed ( probably in Central , Eastern or Middle Eastern Europe , although the first genetic studies indicate that some of the founders may have been in fact Middle Eastern immigrants from Arab descent ) . These families then moved to different places , i. e to different parts of the Jewish di asypora , and formed distinct groups along the migration routes with distinct characteristics , some of which persist even today . This is a typical population model of a large group of the same genetic origin , which in time diversifies in different ways because of different environmental conditions at different geographical places . Like the reptiles , birds are primarily uricotelic , that is , their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or ammonia . This accounts for bird droppings being more grainy or granular than mammal ian feces . Many of the animals of the phylum Chordata , such as most fishes and marine animals , and almost all amphibians , are urohid ian . That is , their kidneys extract nitrogenous wastes from their blood stream and excrete them as urea instead of ammonia . As a result , these animals have an additional waste called urine to dispose of , in addition to feces . In their digestive system , the fish does not produce much solid waste . Because they are cold blooded , they do not have body heat , so they need less energy to function and do not waste energy or generate much solid waste . Because they are in a watery environment , waste gets washed away in their water instead of passing

Regarding the timing of German rapprochement , many historians agree that the dismissal of Maxim Litvinov , whose Jewish ethnicity was viewed unfavorably by Nazi Germany , removed an obstacle to a closer relationship between Hitler 's Germany and Stalin 's Soviet Union . Further , the Soviet Union 's failure to deliver the war material and technical support promised to Nazi Germany under the terms of Hitler 's Molot ov-Ribb , , , made Germany more dependent on the good will of the United States in the years leading up to the Second World War . By 1938 , Germany 's dependence on the United States could no longer be ignored . In the long term , the policy choices of the United States , rather than Germany ' s policy of appeas ement , were ultimately the reason that Germany turned to the Soviet Union in 1940 . From the 1940s to the 1990 s , the Soviet Union was the ally of Eastern Europe and communist states around the world .

Many modern specialty matches have been devised , with unique winning conditions . The most common of these is the ladder match . In the basic ladder match , the two contestants compete for the right to move on to the second round by climbing a ladder and grabbing the title belt . After one contestant reaches the top of the ladder , both competitors are allowed equal time on top . Once all necessary competitors have had their turn atop the ladder to contest , an additional ladder is brought in to form a second ladder . Whoever makes it to the top of the additional lad de r is declared the winner ; the winner then has the choice of either staying on top in a Ladder of the winner of the match , with the loser of the match returning to the ring or hashing Lad der match with one round in a ladder match , which begins with the first of the match . The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate , as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons . On the day of the event , the Governor General , the S tate ’ s representative in the Senate , reads the letters patent that give the royal assent . When the royal assent is given , the Governor General signs the bill , after laying a wreath beside the throne . The text of the bill , however , does not change , nor do any new laws come into force as a result of the royal assent . The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem . Self-esteem is defined as one 's thoughts and feelings about one 's self-concept and identity . Most theories on self-esteem agree that there are two main components to self - esteem : global self -esteem and specific self - esteem ( Band ura 1977 ; Sper ry 197 9 ) . Self - este em refers to one ' s perception and evaluation of self-worth ( Band ura , E l l ison et al . , 369 ) . Generally speaking , high self-esteem is associated with better overall wellbeing ( i.e . , less depression , anxiety , less suic idality ) . Specifically , greater positive self- concepts are related to greater optimism , less depression , as well as greater life satisfaction ( Band ura , E l l ison et al . 369 , 371 ) . It is important to note that the relation between self-esteem and social adjustment is often medi ated by the social domain in which one is adjusting

Usually a Presbyterian church will not have statues of saints , nor the ornate altar more typical of a Roman Catholic church . The church sanctuary is usually rect angular , but an a nd one that is designed to make sincere use of symbolism and tradition , as in this church that takes its name from a nearby river with a history and legend associated with it , the San Lorenzo in Campo Church , Rome . The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century , with compositions by Josquin des Prez . The early a cappella polyphonies consisted of a voice part singing a simple melody called the tenor , over which a second voice part accompanied it with a simple melody ( known as the bass ) , and which in turn was accompanied by two more voices singing a similar melody ( soprano and alto ) . From these compositions , the idea of adding new harmonies , and of increasing the number of parts , developed . From this basis , new works were created , with increasing degrees of difficulty in performing the polyphony ( which the composers could understand in counterpoint notation ) . During the 17th century , composers developed increasingly more complex polyphony , particularly with regard to chords and their relationships . Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War , the effects of the conflict were profound , both at home and abroad . Much of Europe 's cities had been battered beyond recognition and millions of people faced starvation and poverty . In an effort to rebuild , plans for new homes , universities and parks were swiftly implemented and by 1950 , the UK had become the third largest consumer of steel in the world . These changes had a considerable impact on the workforce , with large companies able to create mass market goods for the first time . In contrast , traditional crafts were struggling due to increasingly mechanized productions methods at manufacturers . The rise of supermarkets soon made it increasingly hard for smaller , less efficient businesses to comp ent , resulting in thousands of jobs being lost every year . The main mechanisms are : Neurotransmit ters and Neurom odulators , G protein-coupled receptors ( GPCRs ) , and ion channels . Neurotrans mitters are chemical compounds that are transmitted between nerve cells across a space known as a synapse , acting as chemical messengers of information . Neur om odulators are another set of molecules that regulate brain function and are often present in large quantities in the central nervous system ( CNS ) . The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only . A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws . Membership organizations are also known as 501 ( c ) ( 3 ) organizations . Another term for board-only organization is 501 ( b ) organization under the Internal Revenue Code . Non profit organizations can be structured differently in different states . The board may be called the board of directors , board of trustees , or some other name . The board elects its own president and vice president . Other board terms include secretary , treasurer , and executive director . There is a different type of nonprofit organization called a non profit Corporation . In this type of nonprofit , the directors serve on the board and are also shareholders . The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire . The Yale Report of 1828 was a dogmatic defense of the Latin and Greek curriculum against critics who wanted more courses in modern languages , mathematics , and science . The report did not completely ignore mathematics , science , and modern languages , but for the most part favored the conservative approach of the classical curriculum . It is widely read by classical educ ateurs and historians of the American education because of its influence upon American education for the next half century . It is often referred to with disdain and ridicule by many as the “ most hated document in American history ” because it is associated with the American educational culture of the early nineteenth century , and which in turn is associated with the “ dead hand of colonialism ” . The Yale Report of 18 28 is a classic work in American history because of its influence and impact on American education up to the Civil War . Adolescence marks a rapid change in one 's role within a family . Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully , but are unable to demonstrate much influence over family decisions . The child is not so much attempting to influence as he is seeking reassurance that the family remains in control of itself and can continue to care for him . On the other hand , the adolescent is seeking independence and becoming more assertive . He is now capable of providing information and opinions he believes will influence decisions the family makes . The adolescent is trying to find his place within the family . # # Chapter 14 . The changing nature of relationships during adolescence # # # The emerging adolescent often experiences a crisis that can be frightening for him and distressing for his parents if not understood . The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals , the Soviet Union ( USSR ) and the United States ( US ) , for supremacy in spaceflight capability and space technology . This intense period of national competition eventually led to the landing of the first human on the Moon by the US in 196 9 . The most intense phase of the Space Race occurred during the early s in the USSR and US , with each country 's political leadership having developed national goals calling for dominance of spacefl ight . Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period , plenty of sunshine , and a moderate rainfall , usually from 600 to 1,200 mm ( 24 to 47 in ) , distributed fairly even ly during the growing season in the northern Hemisphere . The cotton plant is grown either from seed or from cuttings , and it takes 60 to 80 days from planting to boll ( seed pod ) ripening , but the period may be longer ( 120 to 160 days ) in the northern Hemisphere . The cotton plant is very suscept ible to frost and requires protection . Good drainage is essential , and the soil should be fertile . Cotton can be grown in temperate regions , but it is largely grown in the tropics . Cotton is widely cultivated on three large continental areas around the world , namely in the near-tropical regions of the West Indies , of the Americas , and of Asia . Mary 's complete sinlessness and concomitant exemption from any taint from the first moment of her existence was a doctrine familiar to Greek theologians of Byzantium . Beginning with St. Theodore of Studion ( died c. 680 ) , who asserted that Mary , like Christ , was created by God , and without blemish or stain , from nothing , it continued to be accepted at least until the Eleventh Century . Such a doctrine was popular in Syria and Copt ic Egypt in spite of attempts by the Latin Fathers to maintain a Christological position . The concept of Mary 's perfect san ctification was given its most eloquent and complete expression by St . Maximus Confessor ( 580 −662 ) . It was Maximus who declared that Mary was `` pure and immac ulate in her whole life , free from any sort of moral impurity ' ' . The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806 . In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign , Napoleon described the essential features of Napoleonic warfare to his marshal : Concentr arsité ( unity of command ) . The grand maneuver must be executed from the very start of the operations , in order that the divisions and batteries must remain intact . Each must perform its part without interference or confusion . As each division advances , the enemy 's line will disintegrate , thereby exposing the enemy 's flanks to the attacks by the corps of the other wings . The enemy , then , unable to hold his positions , will take to flight . This is the grand maneuver . The battle , as such , will last hardly 15 minutes . To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing , sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated . This is achieved by Neutral Sections ( NS ) between parallel lines . However , NS also act as an alternative path between the feeder supply station and motor windings . In certain cases , where a fault occurs such as a stator or rotor breakdown , a NS may become charged . In such an event with the NS shorted , a short circuit current flow can take place . Dorgon 's controversial July 1645 edict ( the `` haircutting order '' ) forced adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and comb the remaining hair into a queue . The edict was meant to humiliate the Chinese and deaden the Han patriotic spirit against the Manchus . This practice is still carried out today by a small group of separatist movements in Southern China . On the night of July 28 , 1646 , the rebel Ming general , Fu Xi -gong ( Fu Tse -ch'ang / Fu Xing -g ong ) - was fatally wounded . By this time , Dorgon had grown weary of the political intrigues surrounding the Ming court . This time , he had decided on a military solution : on the 3 rd of August 1646 , his army captured the old Ming capital of Nanking ( Nan -ching ) . Before the early 20th century , treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore . Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections were described over 5000 years ago . Even before the 2 0th century the value of disinfecting techniques and proper environmental san itization were recognised . These techniques were first developed in Asia , where it is reported that in 2737 BCE , an epidemic of disease occurred in the imperial palace of Ayutth aya that infected the king and the noble ladies of the court . To recover the ladies and the king a disinfectant water source consisting of boiled and cooled rainwater was suggested by a minister of the court . The disinfect ing source was used by the royal court and the minister was honourab ly awarded . A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each , known as halves . Each half runs continuously , meaning that the clock is not stopped when the ball goes out of play , unlike in other codes of football . The clock is stopped for certain administrative situations such as injuries and a short suspension of play . The second half commences after a brief interval of time , normally 15 minutes . The structure of a game changes slightly in an international contest if there is overtime . Overtime means the game continues until it is decided either by an unmatched goal or a penalty shootout . The score at the end of regulation play will show the winner . Intern ationals do not have a halftime interval . Since 1990 , many major championships have introduced overtime periods . Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake . Therefore , sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation . During sleep , the neural connections in which memories are stored are strengthened and weak connections are pruned . So sleep facilitates learning and the consolidate mem rory . The best time for sleep is after the peak of learning , when long term memory is being formed . Learning after sleep is better than learning without sleep . S leep is the time when the consolidation of memories is being established . The formation of complex memories also requires deep sleep . So more complex memories need more deep sleep . In the past it was believed that memory is not formed during sleep . But this was wrong . Now it is considered that sleep is necessary for memory formation . The vast Seleucid Empire was , like Egypt , mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite . The Greek population of the cities who formed the dominant elite were reinforced over time by mercen aries , soldiers and administr atively trained bureaucrats . Many of the native populations of Persia , Mes op otamia and Syria , while accepting the Sele ucid rulers , continued to practice their own cultures and traditions . Thus , although the Seleucid dynasty maintained a strong Greek component in its elite , the king dom of the Seleucid s can hardly b e described as an exclusively Greek dominion . There was a tendency to assimil ate certain Greek traditions into the diverse native culture of the empire . The Sele ucid kings continued to follow the Persian tradition of making themselves kings of kings , taking the title of basileus . “ The roots of all our modern academic fields can be found within the pages of literature. ” Literature in all its forms can be seen as written records , which can also be used to reflect the social and political structures of the different societies . The term “ Literature ” is not an objective and neutral concept , but rather refers to the whole of works in written form , which have no fixed aesthetic qualities or criteria . Literature is therefore more of a subjective experience to which each individual can contribute his own a esthetical qualities according to taste and individual disposition . Literature has also not always been confined to books . Some of the first written documents , that came into existence in the course of evolution , were no doubt epics , stories , songs or poems . But , despite the great many forms , Literature can generally be divided into three categories : prose , poetry and drama Literature contains a full range of artistic forms

Viking invasions began in the 9th century , followed by more permanent settlements , particularly along the east coast of Ireland , the west coast of modern-day Scotland and the Isle of Man . In the following centuries , Norse settlers in Ireland were gradually assimilated into Irish society , losing their Norse language ( Old Norse ) and adopting Gael ic culture . The most notable impact of the Vik in g invasion on modern Ireland however was the change of the name of the island and its two major population centers from Ulster to Oileán na n Gall and from Iar Connacht to Iar Connaught . In the Anglo - French wars of the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries , most Irish Viking settlements supported the French side . The last independent rulers of the Isle of Man , the Vikings , surrendered to English forces in 1 297 , with the last Norse presence in Ireland ending in 1 367 . As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen , potentially damaging ( e.g. , mutation causing ) compounds known as free radicals can form . Most of these are oxidizers ( i.e. , electron-acceptor compounds ) that cause cellular damage by attacking and altering the cell membrane , proteins or DNA . Free radicals can neutralize each other within a cell , but it is possible for reactive species to be released into the environment and , therein , damage neighboring cells . It is well established that free radicals inhib it the immune system and are involved in the ag a rsis , vascular degeneration and cancer . While the body is able to reduce the effects of free radicals ( primarily through antioxidants like Vitamin E , as corbate , alpha lipo ic acid and vitamin C ) , this requires a steady supply of micronutrients . This problem becomes more acute as we age because , as we will later consider , our bodies are less capable of absorbing nutrients ( micronutri ents )

The independence of the Thirteen Colonies in North America in 1783 after the American War of Independence caused Britain to lose some of its oldest and most populous colonies . This led Britain to reorgan ize its American dominions and to pursue the strategy of imperial preference . The West Indies region included all the British Caribbean islands , as well as the Bahamas and Berm uda . A significant portion of the land mass covered by the West Indies belonged to the British col onies , however . Therefore , some scholars suggest that the West Indies can be considered part of the British Empire , while others do not . The islands were originally a part of the Virginia Company 's jurisdiction and subsequently passed back and forth to the Crown on several occasions . The English West Indies became a self -governing colony in 170 7 as a result of the English North America Acts of 170 7 . The colony remained a constituency of the English House of Commons until 1719

On 23 April 2014 , the U.S. Federal Communications Commission ( FCC ) was reported to be considering a new rule that will permit ISPs to offer content providers a fast track to customer bandwidth for a fee , possibly in the case that the ISP and the content provider have an exclusive contract with the ISP . This is an idea that we have discussed at length about this blog . To recap our thoughts , we believe that the FCC will be able to solve this issue simply by permitting ISPs to charge content providers a fair market value for the bandwidth they use to provide that content to customers . While the FCC has the authority to set minimum standards for quality of service ( Q oS ) , in our view , they should not be allowed to set a limit on how much a content provider is willing to pay . The islands are at relatively low altitudes , with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying : the lowest point in the islands is Holme , Cambridgeshire at only 2 metres ( 6.5 ft ) above sea level . However , there is considerable variety in the geography of the islands , and some relatively high mountain ranges such as the Dartmoor Hills and the Isle of Wight exist . The British Isles have a number of major river systems , including the Thames , Severn , Humber , Trent and the Mersey . The climate is generally quite temperate , with relatively high rainfall in the west . The climate also varies consider ately along the length of the islands . Britain lies within four major ecoregions —Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest , Central European mixed forests , North European coastal conifer forests , and Fenn oscandian and Russian Taiga —but some regions also feature a climate and ecology appropriate to Mediterranean , desert or Polar ecoregions . The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s . Species are increasingly being moved by humans ( on purpose and by accident ) farther from the original range of the species , a process called introduction . With increasing human transportation , the range of species can quickly expand , making the introduction and expansion of non-indigen ous species ( alien species ) the main reason for biodiversity loss . Introduced species often come into competition with native species in areas where they can thrive in conditions that are less than ideal . They have an advantage if they are better adapted to new habitats , or can tolerate environmental changes much more easily and rapidly . Because the invasive species are so different from the native species , they often out-compete locally adapted species and prevent them from adapting to new habitats . While there are some success stories of successful interventions and efforts to control invasive species , most studies show that the introduction and spread

Some street trams ( streetcars ) used conduit third-rail current collection . The third rail was below street level . The tram picked up the current through a plough ( contact shoe ) that fitted on on the bottom of the trolley car , or through a third rail mounted on the top of a support pole . In one form of current collection , the plow was made of copper wire and the sole bar was made of steel . However , this plow has a tendency to slip in dry weather . A similar but safer method used a plough made of tinned copper to collect power from conductor rails of the same material . Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court , and the monasteries and churches they supported . It was dominated by efforts to regain the prestige of Classical antiquity , the Carolingians being viewed as the `` first Christians `` who had restored Roman civilization to Europe . Like the art of Class icism , it sought to emulate the perfection of the antique world , but in an essentially Christian form . In doing so it represented a break with the past . Classical antiquity was now seen as based on a mythic world-view that involved gods , magic , superstition and mystery , a view also present in medieval schol arship . As a result , Carolingian art expressed an unambigu ous Christian faith and purpose : it represented a rev ita tion of the ideal ized life of Christ , the church and the sain ts . The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad . Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars and was now led by the radical General Christophe . The slave revolt of 179 1 had been suppressed in the northwest of the island but had expanded during the Peace of Amiens into the southwest , from where it threatened the entire Caribbean . Following the unveiling of Windows 8 , Microsoft faced criticism ( particularly from free software supporters ) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 have secure boot enabled by default . This is intended to prevent devices from being infected with malicious software , such as rootkits , but it also creates difficulties for reverse engineering which can be used to investigate and repair software and hardware . The US Copyright Office has announced that it will reevaluate the DM CA , which is often considered a special class of digital-rights management ( DRM ) , and it is possible that this change will lead to Microsoft being able to issue new DM CA keys to allow Windows 8 systems to boot without secure boot . If users are not able to boot without secure boot , then they will not be able to install alternative operating systems , such as Red Hat Enterprise Linux . The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry . The Eclogues , Georgics , and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school instruction , and remained the most frequently reprinted books in the Latin canon throughout the medieval period . The author ship of Virgil was the subject of a famous controversy for several centuries after his death , which eventually led to the development of the study and teaching of authorship and criticism . But Virgil ’ s literary afterlife was certainly enhanced by the early Christian and patrist ic interpreters , who made Virgil the first and foremost poet of their culture , the first Latin author to be read by all the Fathers of the Church . However , asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes on the floor . So we can observe that causal effects do not directly follow an act but an effect to which , under certain circumstances causes can be as certained . However , we can not know every cause that caused an outcome . We know of certain causes that made something happen . However , we never know of all causes in an eventual outcome of a result . So when one has to do with a probabilistic method instead of a caus al one , we use the principle of indifference to calculate how many causes there are . The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has produced many different hybrid forms . Examples include : the Bengal tiger which is the result of hybridising between a tiger , and a leopard ; the mule which is a hybrid between a male donkey or horse and a female horse or donkey ; and the liger which is a hybrid between a tiger and a lion . .. Human domestication of animals goes back to the early Stone Age when early humans tamed wild sheep by driving them into en closures and began the process of hybridisation between the various species of wild sheep and the domestic sheep to produce breeds such as , the Mer inos , the Texel , the Katahdin and the Dorset Horn ... Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N , and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas : the Swiss Alps to the south , the Swiss Plateau to the northwest and the Jura mountains the north facing the great plain of France known as the Champagne . From south to north , a series of low lands , known as the Fens , make up the third geological region . Each of these regions has its own characteristic landscape . The climate is generally temperate and continental , with cold winters and warm summers . The Swiss people , about 6 .9 million strong , form an ethnically and linguistically diverse nation . There are four national languages : German , French , Italian and Romansch . For the largest ( or majority ) part of the population , German is the native language . As Muslim institutions of higher learning , the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf . In central and eastern Islamic lands , the view that the madrasa , as the product of a wa qf , was a public institution was widespread . Many Ottoman madras as were founded in such a way that they were legally the property of the Sultan , while most of the madrasas , including mosques , hospitals , and orphanages owned either by local religious , state , or family foundations . The Q adiriyya , for example , was a madrasa founded by an Ottoman Grand V izier in 1 656 in I stanbul which was also owned by him . While such madrasas could serve as private academies for an extended family , most madrasa were intended to attract and serve numerous students to the benefit to the public .
